description:
Bare Knuckle Mobile is an official Streets of Rage game produced by Sega with music by Yuzo Koshiro. The game is essentially a remake of the first SoR, but with higher resolution graphics, new sounds and musical arrangements. Most character sprites are adapted versions of the ones found in SoR 2 (although Blaze is actually a combination of her SoR 1 & 2 appearances), while others did not appear in SoR 2, but were designed in order to be in harmony with the rest.

Unlike SoR 1, there are just two playable characters: Axel Stone and Blaze Fielding. On the other hand, Adam Hunter will appear as a guide in the initial tutorial, and will join you later on in the game as a CPU-controlled backup character for a while. Also, the number of levels has been lowered to seven, now the second level will be the beach (the third level in the original game), although surprisingly its final boss will be Zamza. The game sports some new sprites which have re-imagined some classic SoR 1 enemies in a SoR 2 style, and also features a brand new boss character called Harakiri, who replaces Big Ben. The stages are basically improved versions of those found in SoR 1.
title: Bare Knuckle Mobile

description:
This i-mode game for the FOMA90x platform is the direct sequel to the 1986 arcade game Athena. After the events of the first game, Princess Athena has become bored with peace and adventure-free lifestyle. To fix this problem, she opens the Door Which Shoudn't Be Opened: B. This time she is joined by her maid Helene as they journey into the Elysium World.

Gameplay is similar to the original, but it features two playable characters (Athena and Helene), and has an omake mode.
title: Athena: Full Throttle

description:
Pokémate is a Pokémon-themed mobile phone game. Players are given a Pokémon and ten Poké Balls when they start the game. The Poké Balls are used to catch more Pokémon, just like the main series. However, if the player doesn't pay for the monthly subscription, they are only allowed to catch three Pokémon. Caught Pokémon are sent to the storage area, where the player can view their Pokédex entries and change their avatar, which can be set to any Pokémon they have caught. Pokémon are taken care of, like a virtual pet, rather than used in battles.

The game also has a communication feature where players can talk to up to 16 other players via voice mail and e-mail.
title: Pokémate

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Hokkaido with Yukiho Hagiwara. Which places the player and Yukiho visit is determined by rolling dice, and Yukiho takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Hokkaidō no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Okayama with Chihaya Kisaragi. Which places the player and Chihaya visit is determined by rolling dice, and Chihaya takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Okayama no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Yokohama with Iori Minase. Which places the player and Iori visit is determined by rolling dice, and Iori takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Yokohama no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Nagoya with Azusa Miura. Which places the player and Azusa visit is determined by rolling dice, and Azusa takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Nagoya no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Tokyo with Ritsuko Akizuki. Which places the player and Ritsuko visit is determined by rolling dice, and Ritsuko takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Tokyo no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Kyoto with Haruka Amami. Which places the player and Haruka visit is determined by rolling dice, and Haruka takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Kyoto no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Okinawa with Makoto Kikuchi. Which places the player and Makoto visit is determined by rolling dice, and Makoto takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Okinawa no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Fukuoka with Ami and Mami Futami. Which places the player and the twins visit is determined by rolling dice, and one of the twins takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Fukuoka no Tabi

description: This game is from the H@PPENING LOC@TION series, in which players travel around locations in Japan with idols from the arcade game THE iDOLM@STER. In this game, the player travels around Osaka and Kobe with Yayoi Takatsuki. Which places the player and Yayoi visit is determined by rolling dice, and Yayoi takes the number of steps rolled in order to land on a place.
title: H@PPENING LOC@TION: Osaka - Kobe no Tabi

description:
Sonic Tennis is a mobile phone tennis game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog and friends. The player controls Sonic as he plays tennis against three of his friends. Sonic has to win the best of three matches to move on to the next opponent. The opponents are Tails, Amy, and Knuckles.

In 2004, an updated version of the game replaced the original. It had improved graphics to take advantage of newer phone models.
title: Sonic Tennis

description: Not to be confused with the 16-bit original, the 8-bit adaptation, or the otherwise unrelated 2006 game of the same name, Sonic the Hedgehog is a mobile phone game released to commemorate the franchise's 10th anniversary. Similar to the 16-bit original, Sonic runs through zones, collecting rings and defeating Badniks to increase his score.
title: Sonic the Hedgehog

description: Sonic Golf is a mobile phone golf game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog. The player plays through nine holes of golf using a 2D top-down perspective. After the ninth hole, the player can upload the final score to the high score server.
title: Sonic Golf

description: Speed is a mobile phone game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog and friends. Sonic, Tails, Amy, and Knuckles play the card game speed where the goal is to shed all cards as quickly as possible. Sonic can play against computer opponents in One Person mode or against other players in the Competition mode.
title: Speed

description: Sonic Fishing is a mobile phone fishing game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog. In this simple game, the player must catch the biggest fish. There are multiple selectable lures, and each fish is worth a certain amount of points.
title: Sonic Fishing

description: Sonic Billiards is a mobile phone billiards game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog characters. Sonic plays pool against other computer-controlled characters, or against other people in a VS Mode. The game is played from a 2D top-down perspective.
title: Sonic Billiards

description: Nakayoshi Chao! is a mobile phone virtual pet simulator from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. In it, the player raises a Chao. The player keeps the Chao happy and healthy by petting it and talking to it. Wallpapers can also be downloaded through the game.
title: Nakayoshi Chao!

description: Sonic Bowling is a mobile phone bowling game from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. One player can bowl against up to three computer-controlled characters, or 2-4 real players can bowl against each other. Characters include Sonic the Hedgehog, Miles "Tails" Prower, Knuckles the Echidna, and Shadow the Hedgehog.
title: Sonic Bowling

description: Eggman no Kazu Ate Panic! is a mobile phone game from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. In this game, Dr. Eggman has laid several hidden bombs, and it is up to the player in the guise of Tails to defuse them, guessing where they are hidden based on cryptic clues Eggman gives. When the time runs out, the bomb explodes, and the game is over.
title: Eggman no Kazu Ate Panic!

description: Sonic no Jirai Sagashi Game is a mobile phone game from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. It is basically a clone of Minesweeper. In the standard mode, the game is timed, with Dr. Eggman in the top-left corner, whereas landscape mode is not timed, and Sonic is in the top-left corner. The player must determine where mines are hidden in a minefield by digging on squares. Some squares have numbers uncovered when they are dug, which tells the player how many squares away the nearest mine is. Players use these hints to determine the exact location of the mine, and then mark that square. If the player digs on a square where a mine is hidden, it explodes and the player loses the game. There are also blank squares that don't help or hurt the player. Once all mines are correctly marked, the game is won.
title: Sonic no Jirai Sagashi Game

description: Sonic Racing SHIFT UP is a mobile phone kart racing game featuring Sonic the Hedgehog and friends. The player has to shift gears as quickly as possible and at the right time to beat their opponent. The rings the players earn during gameplay can be used to tune up their karts. Shift data is uploaded to a remote server to be compared against players throughout Japan.
title: Sonic Racing SHIFT UP

description:
Kingdom Hearts coded was a mobile game that was released in Japan, exclusively on NTT DoCoMo phones. The initial install contained two playable worlds. These were unrelated to the main story, which was released as episodic downloadable content in eight parts.

The first world available upon initial install was Traverse Town, which was a trimmed down version from the main game, and as such was labeled the "special edit upgrade". Sora could fight heartless here. It also acted as a hub world, allowing travel to the only other world available in the initial install, the Olympus Coliseum.

The "Olympus Coliseum Side Episode" was a small story wherein Sora fought battles at the Olympic Coliseum for the satyr trainer Philoctetes. The Disney hero Hercules also made an appearance here.
title: Kingdom Hearts: Coded

description: This mobile port of Popful Mail was released episodically in late 2003 and early 2004. Stage 1 contains the PC-98 version's first level, the woods. A complete version of the game was released later.
title: Popful Mail: Stage 1

description: This mobile port of Popful Mail was released episodically in late 2003 and early 2004. Stage 2 contains the PC-98 version's second level, the cave. A complete version of the game was released later.
title: Popful Mail: Stage 2

description: This mobile port of Popful Mail was released episodically in late 2003 and early 2004. Stage 3 contains the PC-98 version's third level, the mine. A complete version of the game was released later.
title: Popful Mail: Stage 3

description: This mobile port of Popful Mail was released episodically in late 2003 and early 2004. Stage 4 contains the PC-98 version's fourth level, the ice area. A complete version of the game was released later.
title: Popful Mail: Stage 4

description: This mobile port of Popful Mail was released episodically in late 2003 and early 2004. Stage 5 contains the PC-98 version's last level. A complete version of the game was released later.
title: Popful Mail: Stage 5

description: A port of the Chinese only Contra: Evolution, basically a High Definition remake of the NES version of Contra.
title: Contra

description: Shadow Shoot is a mobile phone game released as part of the Sonic Cafe service offered by SEGA. Players control the character Shadow the Hedgehog where he moves at a constant speed through side-scrolling levels. Movement is largely limited to moving up and down, and sometimes a little left or right, to collect rings and defeat enemies. The overall goal is to beat Dr. Egmman who has stolen the Chaos Emeralds. Enemies can be attacked using a handgun or a spin jump, and attacks can be chained into combos. A boss needs to be defeated at the end of every level. Highscores can be uploaded to an online scores server.
title: Shadow Shoot

description: In Puzzle Makaimura Knight Arthur enters the Makai labyrinth to find and save his beloved princess from the demons. The game plays in many ways like Solomon's Key with player needing to find a key to unlock the door to the next level, while dodging demons and jumping on arrow platforms.
title: Puzzle Makaimura

description: Once again Arthur has to rescue his fair princess in this sequel to Puzzle Makaimura, but this time in depths of hell deep in the Makai labyrinth. The game is pretty much the same as its prequel with a different graphic set, tougher puzzles and 40 new levels.
title: Puzzle Makaimura Revenge

description: Arthur ventures into the deepest part of the Makai labyrinth to save the princess from the demons for the third time. Just like the previous two games, the puzzle elements are the same, but the graphic set is different and the new 40 levels have newer and harder puzzles.
title: Puzzle Makaimura Final

description: Tower Bloxx Mini is a simplified, cut down version of Tower Bloxx designed for NTT DoCoMo's i-widget platform. i-widgets allowed players to set their phone up with quick-launch apps that were available from their phone's start screen at any time. Tower Bloxx Mini focuses on the original game's one-button action puzzle game, condensing it to fit within the i-widgets platform's limits.
title: Tower Bloxx Mini

description: Tobidasu! Tower Bloxx 6-D is a stereoscopic 3D take on Tower Bloxx. Making use of red-cyan stereoscopic graphics, players wearing 3D glasses can experience the artwork in 3D. The presentation has been updated to emphasize the perspective, with objects leaning into the screen, while the gameplay stays mostly the same.
title: Tobidasu! Tower Bloxx 6-D

description:
Odin's prophecy gives humanity only a single year before the Demon King's return. Humanity's response: train up a hero who can defeat him and save the world. In this traditional RPG, players take on the role of the hero in that fateful year. Given a limited amount of time, they must pick their moves carefully. There are 15 different unique allies the player can recruit and a large number of different events they can encounter, and the player's actions determine the outcome of the story. Because of the limited slice of the game players can experience on each playthrough, they're encouraged to replay many times to see different possible outcomes. Players who are persistent enough are rewarded with the chance to see the true ending.

This game takes place in an alternate timeline to the original game with players taking on the role of Sophitia, one of the original game's recruitable characters. She's joined by a new set of 15 allies, replacing the original game's cast. The Demon King is different this time, too, but with a twist: there are actually several different Demon Kings, with the antagonist for a particular playthrough selected at random at the start of every game.
title: Maou ga Ochiru Hi II

description:
Editor-turned-detective Izumi Kido returns once more in her third mystery. These games are known for being set in well-researched real-world environments; this time takes her to Kagoshima, a city southwest in Kyushu known for its bay and its hot climate.

This Japanese-style mystery adventure game is text-heavy and menu-driven, with players interviewing witnesses and making choices via menus. An epilogue was available on G-Mode's mobile website for players who had completed the game.
title: Izumi Jiken Files: Yujuku-hen

description:
Set soon after solving the mystery in the first game, Izumi Kido found herself hoping to get back to her real job of editing Masamune Kagami's next novel. Unfortunately, just as the two of them arrive at Osaka's Mount Tenpo, they encounter yet another death - the body of a young man whose relationship had just ended, next to a suicide note and sleeping pills. To most observers this is a straightforward case of suicide, but Kagami is unconvinced; with inconsistencies he sees on the scene and seemingly irrational behaviour from the victim, he decides there must be some sort of foul play. For Kido, this means that if she wants to get Kagami's mind back on the manuscript he owes her, she's going to have to solve the case.

This Japanese-style mystery adventure game is text-heavy and menu-driven, with players interviewing witnesses and making choices via menus. The Izumi Jiken Files series is known for being set in well-researched real-world environments; this game takes place in Mount Tenpo and other famous Osaka settings.
title: Izumi Jiken Files: Tasogare-hen

description:
Editor-turned-detective Izumi Kido returns in her fourth mystery. These games are known for being set in well-researched real-world environments; this time takes her to Hokkaido, the colder northern region of Japan. This entry was the first to require DoCoMo's newer FOMA 900i phones, allowing for much more advanced artwork than previous games.

This Japanese-style mystery adventure game is text-heavy and menu-driven, with players interviewing witnesses and making choices via menus. An epilogue was available on G-Mode's mobile website for players who had completed the game.
title: Izumi Jiken Files: Yukika-hen

description:
Editor-turned-detective Izumi Kido returns one more time, with her adventures taking her to another well-known region of Japan. The then-advanced graphical capabilities of DoCoMo's FOMA 700i phones are used to reproduce the sights of the region in great detail. As in previous games, she's nominally assigned to work as the editor for the author Masamune Kagami, but he's easily distracted and becomes involved in solving a mystery instead of writing the manuscript he owes her. In order to ensure she gets his manuscript in on time, she's forced to solve the mystery herself.

This Japanese-style mystery adventure game is text-heavy and menu-driven, with players interviewing witnesses and making choices via menus. An in-game notebook lets players keep track of evidence and suspects.
title: Izumi Jiken Files: Kimikage-hen

description: This is the first in a series of mobile spinoffs from Compile's 2001 Game Boy Advance game Guru Logi Champ. Like in the original game, players control a small cannon that fires blocks into a playfield, with the goal of filling in missing squares. By rotating the playfield and carefully manipulating game pieces, players can fill in the blanks and complete stages. This spinoff features a wider playfield than the original game.
title: Guru Logi Champ Rescue 1

description: This is part of a series of mobile spinoffs from Compile's 2001 Game Boy Advance game Guru Logi Champ. Like in the original game, players control a small cannon that fires blocks into a playfield, with the goal of filling in missing squares. By rotating the playfield and carefully manipulating game pieces, players can fill in the blanks and complete stages. This spinoff features a wider playfield than the original game.
title: Guru Logi Champ Rescue 3

description:
Real: Another Edition is a Japanese exclusive alternate reality cell phone game from the Project Zero / Fatal Frame series. It was distributed through the i-mode mobile internet service, requiring a monthly subscription of 525 Japanese Yen.

Players take photographs with their phones of their real world environments, superimposing ghosts in them. Players then would "enter" the photograph to see the ghost in a first person 3D environment as they exorcise them by taking well aimed and timed photos of the ghosts like in the other games of the series.

While capturing one of the over 70 ghosts available, the player will be given hints or other messages in their mail about the possible locations where to find one of the ghosts.

The game also allowed players to store photographs they've taken of ghosts on the online server provided.

REAL stands for Reveal, Enclose, Appear, Let's shoot.
title: Real: Another Edition

description:
Rengoku is a mobile phone version of Rengoku: The Tower of Purgatory.

The players take control of the cybernetic robot G.R.A.M., searching for a meaning behind their existence in a world where robots have been imprisoned in a giant tower after their mission to protect humanity ended.

There are seven levels to explore where the player takes on the other androids left stranded, endlessly fighting each other. The player can equip up to six different types of weaponry, and customize their cyborg's head, arms, torso, legs and weaponry.

Rengoku was distributed through the i-mode mobile internet service.
title: Rengoku

description:
Rengoku: The Network of Deucalion is a mobile phone adaptation of Rengoku: The Tower of Purgatory released through the Hudson Soft's HUDSON Real3D subscription service for the FOMA 901i and 902i series cell phones. The game required a monthly 300 yen (315 yen including tax) subscription fee.

After mankind found peace, robots used in warfare were discarded into a tower called the Purgatory. You take control of such an Autonomous Combat Weapon, ADAM, and must battle others alike you in the tower.

The game features a single player Scenario Mode and a multiplayer Pancration Mode:

In the Scenario Mode, players must clear eight floors of the Purgatory while modifying their ADAM with capsules obtained by defeating enemies. Capsules can be used at Terminals, one of which can be found in each floor, to unlock parts to enhance the ADAM's body parts. Finding Transfer Machines allow the players to enter new levels of the tower once each floor's boss has been cleared.

In the Pancreation Mode, players take on each others to claim the opponent's items to power up their ADAM in a winner-takes-all match. The equipment can be used in the Scenario Mode.
title: Rengoku: The Network of Deucalion

description:
Rengoku: -Rinne-The Curriculum- is the second 3D mobile game adaptation of Rengoku: The Tower of Purgatory released through the Hudson Soft's HUDSON Real3D subscription service for the FOMA 901i and 902i series cell phones. The game required a monthly 300 yen (315 yen including tax) subscription fee.

Following Rengoku: The Network of Deucalion, Rengoku: -Rinne-The Curriculum- places players in control of an artificial soldier robot, ADAM.

Unlike it's predecessor, however, players now fight endless waves of enemies in either time limited or time unlimited modes. You acquire different weapon parts from defeated enemies, and can use them to enhance your ADAM's head, arms, body or legs to become more powerful.

The game featured online rankings through the HUDSON Real3D website.
title: Rengoku: -Rinne-The Curriculum-
